metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of mixed forest station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the mixed forest station eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2020. The site (101.1335° E, 41.9903° N) was located in the Sidaoqiao County, in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region . The elevation is 874 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3B & Li7500DS) was 0.17 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. The water vapor density data were rejected when the negative values occurred. Data during May 8 to 20, 2020 were missing due to instrument malfunction.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: In oasis–desert ecosystems, a data collection method involves using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, along with hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in conducting long-term observations of energy and carbon exchange in arid and semiarid areas?
Example.Answer: A challenge in conducting long-term observations in arid and semiarid areas is dealing with ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, especially in inland river basins like the Tarim River basin.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that offers comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A dataset providing comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions includes observations from land surface flux and meteorological stations in the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'data quality evaluation' mean in the context of observational datasets?
Definition.Answer: Data quality evaluation refers to the process of assessing the accuracy and reliability of observational data. In the context of the mentioned datasets, it includes tests for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, as well as removing data affected by instrument errors or environmental conditions like precipitation. Quality is often categorized into levels, indicating the confidence in the data's accuracy.

Definition.Question: What are 'oasis-desert interactions' in the context of ecosystem research?
Definition.Answer: Oasis-desert interactions refer to the ecological and climatic exchanges that occur between oasis regions and surrounding desert areas. These interactions are critical for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes, which are essential for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in arid regions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges between inland river basins and oasis–desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: Inland river basins face challenges like ecological degradation, drying water bodies, and dust storms which affect data collection, while oasis–desert systems deal with maintaining ecological stability and carbon balance, necessitating long-term monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange using specialized equipment like eddy covariance systems.

Interpretation.Question: How can inconsistencies in hydrometeorological data collection methods affect the interpretation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Inconsistencies in hydrometeorological data collection, such as varying data collection intervals or equipment errors, can lead to inaccurate representation of fluxes and affect the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics. This can impact interpretations of oasis-desert interactions and ecological stability.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring the accuracy of long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions, and how could these affect the interpretation of ecological and climatic trends?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges such as equipment malfunctions, data loss during adverse weather conditions, and calibration issues can compromise dataset accuracy. These challenges can lead to misinterpretations of ecological and climatic trends, affecting assessments of carbon balance and sustainable development in oasis-desert systems.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies could be employed to enhance the quality of data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, and what implications might improved data quality have on understanding oasis-desert interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: Employing advanced quality control measures, such as rigorous data processing and error correction techniques, can enhance data quality. Improved data quality may lead to more accurate interpretations of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux patterns, thereby enriching understanding of oasis-desert interactions and supporting ecological security efforts.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What reasons underlie the need for rigorous data processing and quality control in the collection of turbulent flux data in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Rigorous data processing and quality control are necessary to ensure accuracy and reliability, especially given the challenges of environmental degradation such as drying rivers and land desertification in arid and semiarid inland river basins.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to collect long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial to understand oasis–desert interactions and to maintain ecological stability and socioeconomic development, which are significant for achieving sustainable oasis development and supporting ecological security.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors cause the need to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable oasis development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The balance is necessary to achieve sustainability as oases are vital for ecological environments and economic development in arid regions, particularly in western China, where they support a significant population despite comprising a small area of the region.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using long-term observational datasets to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using long-term observational datasets allows for a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases. It supports the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality and bolsters ecological security and sustainable development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the degradation of the ecological environment in inland river basins have on data collection and research in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The degradation of the ecological environment in inland river basins, such as drying rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensified land desertification, poses challenges to data collection and research. These adverse conditions can complicate the establishment and maintenance of observation stations and may affect the quality and continuity of the collected data, crucial for understanding and mitigating ecological degradation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of auxiliary data, such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, enhance the understanding of oasis–desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters enhances the understanding of oasis–desert systems by providing a comprehensive dataset that captures the interactions between various environmental factors. This approach allows for more accurate modeling and analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, thus supporting more informed decision-making for sustainable development and ecological protection in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis-desert ecosystems using eddy covariance systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The ultimate goal is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is critical for achieving sustainable oasis development, carbon peaking, and carbon neutrality, thus supporting ecological security and socioeconomic development in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of data collection on energy and carbon fluxes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is important to achieve sustainable oasis development and to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, which play a crucial role in the carbon balance of arid regions and within the global carbon cycle.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of using a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to obtain a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial to recognize oasis–desert interactions and to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, especially in the face of climate change and ecological degradation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific steps involved in processing eddy covariance data to ensure quality and accuracy in measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing steps for eddy covariance data include removing outlier values, applying time delay corrections, performing coordinate rotation (double coordinate rotation), applying frequency response corrections, correcting ultrasonic virtual temperature, and applying density (WPL) corrections. Quality evaluation involves testing atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Additionally, data selection includes removing erroneous data due to instrument errors, eliminating data around precipitation events, and excluding data with high missing rates within the original 10Hz data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What protocols are followed to manage missing or erroneous data during the observation period, particularly in challenging environments such as the arid regions of western China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Protocols for managing missing or erroneous data include marking missing data as -6999 and removing data with errors such as instrument malfunction, precipitation events, or high missing rates in the original data. Additionally, during periods like winter when water vapor density shows negative values, these are excluded to maintain data integrity. Data from specific problematic periods, such as storage issues, are also noted as missing.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the long-term collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the eddy covariance system and scintillometer have enabled the long-term collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems. These devices provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, which are essential for understanding ecological interactions in these areas.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and methodologies are necessary to maintain high-quality data collection for understanding oasis and desert system interactions?
Enablement.Answer: High-quality data collection for understanding oasis and desert system interactions requires consistent observational datasets, rigorous data processing, and quality control procedures. It also necessitates conditions such as stable instrumentation, regular data archiving, and sharing practices, alongside well-established flux and meteorological stations throughout the study area.

Expectation.Question: Why might fluctuations in oasis–desert system interactions not be captured accurately by current data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing ecological environment degradation, such as river drying, natural vegetation degradation, and intensified desertification, which could lead to challenges in capturing accurate interactions within oasis–desert systems.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for not achieving expected data quality in flux measurements within oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in flux measurements may arise from ecological environment degradation, frequent dust storms, and the need for long-term observations to ensure data quality and understand the interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: Why might the anticipated outcomes of sustainable oasis development not be met despite data collection efforts?
Expectation.Answer: Despite data collection efforts, sustainable oasis development outcomes might not be met due to the ecological crises faced by inland river basins, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and the impact of climate change on these environments.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems is highly effective for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semiarid regions, as they provide detailed and long-term observational data crucial for understanding the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the challenges faced in maintaining data quality when collecting long-term observational datasets in the oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data quality include addressing issues such as instrument errors, data gaps due to storage problems, and environmental factors like dust storms and precipitation, which require rigorous data processing and quality control procedures to ensure reliable datasets.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential for expanding existing datasets to include additional parameters that might enhance the understanding of oasis-desert interactions?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding existing datasets to include additional parameters, such as more detailed soil and vegetation characteristics or advanced hydrometeorological measurements, could significantly enhance the understanding of oasis-desert interactions and support sustainable development strategies.

Assertion.Answer: The eddy covariance system measures these fluxes by collecting half-hourly turbulent flux data. This involves using high-frequency measurements of wind speed, temperature, and gas concentrations to calculate the vertical fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide.

Assertion.Answer: The data collection methods provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This understanding supports ecological stability and socioeconomic development by informing strategies for carbon peaking, carbon neutrality, and sustainable oasis development.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data collection techniques utilized for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems, focusing on the advantages and limitations of each method.
Request/Directive.Answer: In oasis–desert systems, data collection techniques for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange include the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, with auxiliary hydrometeorological data collected from automatic weather stations. Eddy covariance systems provide precise flux measurements but require complex correction procedures, while scintillometers offer broader spatial averaging. Automatic weather stations offer continuous environmental data but may require regular maintenance to ensure data accuracy.
